name: Vigabatrin
summary: Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic medication used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures.
description: Vigabatrin, marketed under the brand name Sabril, is an irreversible inhibitor of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) transaminase, leading to increased levels of GABA in the brain and reduced neuronal excitability. It is primarily indicated for infantile spasms in patients 1 month to 2 years old and as adjunctive therapy for refractory complex partial seizures in adults and children. Due to the risk of permanent vision loss, its use is restricted under a Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) program.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to vigabatrin or formulation components
monitoring_required: Baseline and periodic visual field testing
MRI in infants (risk of intramyelinic edema)

items: Monotherapy for infantile spasms in patients 1 month to 2 years old
Adjunctive therapy for refractory complex partial seizures in patients ≥10 years inadequately controlled with other treatments

sections.text: Irreversibly inhibits GABA transaminase, increasing GABA levels in the brain and reducing neuronal excitability.

adult.oral: Initial: 500 mg twice daily; may increase by 500 mg twice daily at weekly intervals to a maximum of 3 g/day.

pediatric.oral: Infantile spasms: 50 mg/kg/day in two divided doses; may increase by 25–50 mg/kg/day every 3 days to a maximum of 150 mg/kg/day. Pediatric complex partial seizures: start at 40 mg/kg/day, increase gradually based on response.

items: Powder for oral solution: 500 mg packets

sections.text: Response in infantile spasms may be seen within days; seizure control in partial seizures may take several weeks. Visual field loss may occur at any time during therapy.

serious: permanent bilateral concentric visual field constriction

other: Permanent vision loss risk; available only through Sabril REMS Program
May cause MRI changes in infants
Monitor for psychiatric symptoms including depression and psychosis
Abrupt discontinuation may increase seizure risk

items: Baseline and periodic visual field testing

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; weigh risks and benefits
sections.geriatrics: No specific dosage adjustment; monitor for increased sensitivity

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over at least 1 week to reduce risk of seizure exacerbation.

items: Highly effective for infantile spasms, particularly in tuberous sclerosis complex
Visual field loss risk increases with cumulative dose and duration
Early discontinuation should be considered if no benefit within a few weeks for infantile spasms
